channel.title: Bloomberg Economics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Thailand Slashes Growth Forecast on Impact of Trade War
item.description: Thailand significantly lowered its forecast for economic growth this year as the global trade war undercuts private investment and exports, adding to already-weak consumption at home.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana, Pathom Sangwongwanich

item.title: China Consumption Miss Overshadows Factory Strength Amid Tariffs
item.description: China’s industrial output expanded faster than expected in April while consumption disappointed, highlighting the challenges facing the world’s second-largest economy despite a quick de-escalation of trade tensions with the US.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Fran Wang, Lucille Liu, Yujing Liu

media:content.media:description: Photo by Costfoto/NurPhoto via Getty Images)

item.title: Japan’s Ishiba Says Won’t Fixate on US Trade Talk Time Limits
item.description: Japan won’t compromise its national interests in trade talks with the US by fixating on time limits, Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba said, signaling Tokyo isn’t rushing into an agreement.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba Photographer: Anna Rose Layden/UPI

item.title: Ishiba Rebuffs Tax Cut Demands With Greek Debt Comparison
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba rebuffed calls for tax cuts saying that the nation’s financial conditions are worse than Greece’s.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

item.title: Japan PM Ishiba’s Support Falls, No Ouster Seen Before July
item.description: Support for Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba’s government weakened, according to public opinion surveys published by major Japanese news organizations over the weekend, although it remains unlikely he’ll be ousted before a national election in July.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: China-US Trade Truce Prompts Nations to Consider Tougher Tactics
item.description: China’s defiant stance in negotiating a tariff truce with the US has convinced some countries they need to take a tougher position in their own trade talks with the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Katia Dmitrieva

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump during a Congressional resolution signing in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, on May 9.

item.title: Australia’s Productivity at 60-Year Low as Reforms Selected
item.description: Australia’s Productivity Commission has identified 15 priority reforms to examine in the course of five inquiries it’s conducting for the government to try to boost economic efficiency and raise living standards.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Sydney Harbour, with the Sydney Harbour Bridge and buildings in the central business district (CBD).

item.title: UK Home Asking Prices Rise to Record High as Demand Rebounds
item.description: Asking prices for UK homes rose to a new record high in May and demand picked up in a sign of the property market’s resilience after the end of a tax cut for buyers.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

item.title: Midpoint of Trump Tariff Hiatus to Reveal Increasingly Unsettled World
item.description: Reports in the coming week may give the fullest reading to date of how major economies are faring with trade disruptions, halfway through President Donald Trump’s 90-day hiatus on so-called reciprocal tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Idle gantry cranes at the Port of Long Beach in Long Beach, California, US, on Monday, May 12, 2025. Recent data showed a slump in trade across the Pacific Ocean, fueling worries that Trump's broad tariff agenda could hit American consumers with higher prices and fewer choices and spur a global downturn.

item.title: Australia Set for Another Rate Cut as US-China Tensions Ease
item.description: Australia’s central bank is set to lower interest rates for a second time this year as price pressures ease and US-China trade tensions take a pause, though lingering risks around both suggest the board will remain cautious on the policy path ahead.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey, Matthew Burgess

item.title: US States Likely to Defy US Downgrade to Keep Top Credit Ratings
item.description: US states from Florida to North Carolina and Texas would likely hold onto top-notch credit scores from Moody’s Ratings, mostly because they’re in better fiscal shape than the federal government itself.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Albright, Scott Carpenter

media:content.media:description: The Florida State Capitol Complex in Tallahassee, Florida.

item.title: Israel’s Economy Grew 3.4% in 1Q, Helped by Brief Gaza Ceasefire
item.description: Israel’s economy picked up in the first quarter, helped by a temporary ceasefire in the Gaza Strip that ended in mid-March and has given way to a new escalation in fighting.
item.dc:creator: Galit Altstein

media:content.media:description: Shoppers at the Machane Yehuda market in Jerusalem, Israel, on Sunday, Jan. 12, 2025. Israel's economy has been hit since the conflict began with Hamas' attack in October 2023 and gross domestic product grew slowly relative to most other developed nations last year.

item.title: Bessent Calls Moody’s ‘Lagging Indicator’ of US Fiscal Health
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent downplayed concerns over the US’s government debt and the inflationary impact of tariffs on companies including Walmart Inc., saying the Trump administration is determined to lower federal spending and grow the economy.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, during a House Financial Services Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Bessent said he’s working with US legislators on outbound investment rules for China that would make clear what’s allowed and what’s not.

item.title: UK, EU Wrangle Over Students and Travel Ahead of Reset Summit
item.description: British and European Union negotiators wrangled over measures to ease travel for students, young workers and tourists this weekend, as the two sides raced to resolve policy disputes ahead of a summit meant to reset their fraught relationship.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Jorge Valero, Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, left, and UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer meet last month in Downing Street.

item.title: ECB’s Lagarde Says Euro’s Strength Is Counterintuitive, But Justified
item.description: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde said the recent rise of the euro against the dollar is a consequence of US President Donald Trump’s erratic policies and an opportunity for Europe.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Francois De Beaupuy

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde

item.title: Portugal Holds Third Election in Three Years: What to Watch
item.description: Portugal holds its third election in as many years on Sunday, after Prime Minister Luis Montenegro’s minority government lost a confidence vote in parliament in March.
item.dc:creator: Henrique Almeida, Joao Lima

media:content.media:description: Luis Montenegro, Portugal's prime minister, center, at a street rally on May 16. Photographer: Patricia de Melo Moreira/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: India Restricts Some Imports from Bangladesh as Ties Suffer
item.description: India imposed curbs on imports of ready-made garments and processed food from Bangladesh, as relations between the two neighbors turned sour in recent months.
item.dc:creator: Anup Roy

media:content.media:description: The land port restrictions may further affect the ties between the two nations as India was Bangladesh’s third-biggest trading partner in 2024.

item.title: Canada Says Most Tariffs on US Remain, Pushing Back on Oxford Report
item.description: Canada’s finance minister said the government kept 25% retaliatory tariffs on tens of billions of dollars in US goods, disputing a report from a research firm that suggested it had paused the vast majority of those levies.
item.dc:creator: Derek Decloet

item.title: Australia ‘Up for a Deal’ With the EU After Years of Trade Talks
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said Australia is “up for a deal” with the European Union, sounding a note of cautious optimism after years of trade negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Karen Leigh

media:content.media:description: Anthony Albanese Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

item.title: US Says It’s Not Decided Next Steps on NYC’s Congestion Pricing
item.description: The Trump administration urged a federal judge to refrain from blocking the government from taking any action against New York’s congestion pricing program, saying it hasn’t actually done anything yet.
item.dc:creator: Chris Dolmetsch

media:content.media:description: Congestion Relief Zone signage on Park Avenue in New York, US, on Thursday, April 24, 2025. The Trump administration is threatening to stop future federal approvals for transportation projects in Manhattan and may withhold funding if New York City's congestion pricing program continues.

item.title: Trump’s Deals Cast China Both as Foe and Prize, Blurring Signals
item.description: Pick through the details of recent US trade negotiations and an outline of Donald Trump’s vision for the global economy starts to come into focus. As do its contradictions.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, right, and Howard Lutnick, US commerce secretary

item.title: Saudi Arabia Plays Trump Card in US-China Dance
item.description: A 1945 meeting between President Franklin D. Roosevelt and King Abdulaziz Al Saud might be regarded as something of interest only to modern-history buffs. But this week, images of that pivotal tête-à-tête between the US and Saudi leaders circulated in news and social media as President Donald Trump visited the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

media:content.media:description: Members of the entourage of Saudi Arabia’s King Abdulaziz Al Saud aboard the USS Quincy at the Great Bitter Lake in the Suez Canal in February, 1945. As President Donald Trump visited Saudi Arabia this week, local news and social media recalled the historic meeting of President Franklin Delano Roosevelt and the Saudi monarch, which set bilateral ties for decades.

item.title: Charting the Global Economy: US, China Forecasts Improve on Tariff Truce
item.description: Economists marked up their forecasts for growth in the US and China after the world’s two-largest economies reached a temporary agreement to reduce tariffs on each other.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle, Molly Smith

media:content.media:description: Gantry cranes and shipping containers at the Yangshan Deepwater Port in Shanghai, China, early on Monday, Jan. 20, 2025. China is facing a repeat of the tensions and uncertainty from the first presidency of Donald Trump, only with a weaker economy that’s even more reliant on exports than it was during the first trade war with the US.

item.title: ECB’s Schnabel Says ‘Steady Hand’ Needed on Interest Rates
item.description: The European Central Bank should remain cautious on interest-rate moves, according to Executive Board member Isabel Schnabel.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Isabel Schnabel, executive board member of the European Central Bank, during an interview at the ECB in Frankfurt, Germany, on Monday, Nov. 25, 2024. “Given the inflation outlook, I think we can gradually move toward neutral if the incoming data continue to confirm our baseline,” Schnabel said.

item.title: US Loses Last Top Credit Rating With Downgrade From Moody’s
item.description: The US was stripped of its last top credit rating by Moody’s Ratings, reflecting deepening concern that ballooning debt and deficits will damage America’s standing as the preeminent destination for global capital and increase the government’s borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie

item.title: Bank of England Forecast Shake-Up Risks Sowing Market Confusion
item.description: Former Bank of England ratesetters are warning that a planned shake-up of the central bank’s forecast and communications strategy risks sowing confusion in financial markets and weakening debate among policymakers.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Andrew Bailey Photographer: Jaimi Joy/Bloomberg
